item.title: The Internet and the Human Brain
item.dc:creator: Jon

item.content:encoded:
Last fall, my dad spent a few days with me while he was in town (then Mankato, MN) for meetings. We ended up having some really interesting conversations one evenings. I’d like to share some of that discussion, only a few months late.

A little background: my dad is non-techie. He is pretty limited to reading and writing emails, and even that was a stretch at first. So that makes his observation a little more interesting, at least to me.

But on that evening, we somehow got on a few technical topics. After awhile, my dad made an interesting observation, comparing the internet to the human brain.

A little more background, a few years my dad had brain surgery to remove a tumor. So that explains some of his interest in the brain.

Anyways, we went on to other topics, including finding his former college roommate on LinkedIn. But I returned to his comment about the brain and the internet as I trying to fall asleep that night. And I realized he had a good point. The internet shares behavior with the human brain.

When a route on the internet gets really slow or fails all together, traffic will adjust its flow to use faster paths to their destination. This could be called self-healing.

In a similar fashion, the brain also self-heals. If a pathway is blocked because a neuron has died, then the other neurons will try to find another pathway. Or in the extreme case of brain surgery, entire sections of the brain will re-wire themselves.

While technological advances are amazing, it’s more amazing to think about similar processes that have always been a part of us.

item.title: Tracking Progress
item.dc:creator: Jon
item.description: At the beginning of my apprenticeship, I asked for some general advice during a meeting on my first day. Dave Hoover pointed out that the apprenticeship goes by very quickly so it’s a good idea to have short-term goals in … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
At the beginning of my apprenticeship, I asked for some general advice during a meeting on my first day. Dave Hoover pointed out that the apprenticeship goes by very quickly so it’s a good idea to have short-term goals in mind.

As Dave mentioned that, I thought a tool that would be perfect for capturing my thoughts on a daily basis and hopefully facilitate retrospection on my progress and growth. And that tool is MercuryApp.

I had previously used MercuryApp off and on to track variously things, but with no real goal in sight. With my apprenticeship, I want to be able to look back at a certain day or week and remember how I was feeling. What bugged me that day? What went great? Did I have any breakthroughs? Or perhaps a major headache? I hope MercuryApp helps me think back on my apprenticeship and make sure I am heading in the right direction. I’ve already found MercuryApp for my weekly checkin meetings.

I am using another means to keep track of various technical revelations that come to me on a daily basis. Some of my most frustrating experiences are times when I know I’ve solved some problem in the past but cannot remember how I did it. My only real solution is to try to remember what day I figured this out in the past so I can review my browser history that day, because more than likely I found the answer online.

To try to stop that from happening, I’ve started a wiki where I’m posting “Learning Notes” so I can keep track of information that solved a problem or an article that I found particular interesting. I’m also writing down quotes or interesting tidbits from books I read, starting with The RSpec Book.

Here’s to using technology to bolster my memory!

item.title: Why Apprenticeship?
item.dc:creator: Jon
item.description: I thought it would be a good idea to write down some of the reasons why I looked into becoming an apprentice. Kind of a “can’t move forward without knowing where you’ve been” idea. First, and probably least important, was … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
I thought it would be a good idea to write down some of the reasons why I looked into becoming an apprentice. Kind of a “can’t move forward without knowing where you’ve been” idea.

First, and probably least important, was a general lack of fulfillment at my previous job. I enjoyed working with all of my coworkers, but the work really wasn’t something I was enjoying. Looking back on it, I think that lack of fulfillment dampened my enthusiasm towards personal projects and learning.

Second, the apprenticeship is a great learning and growth opportunity. Apprentices at Obtiva are in a position to gain so much knowledge from their coworkers. By the end of my first day, I’m already humbled and inspired by the skill level around me. Quite a learning curve and learning opportunity.

Third, and most importantly, I became an apprentice because of my wife, which is a strange thought since we’ll be living 400 miles away for the duration of the apprenticeship. But on my first evening alone in Chicago, I realized Tanya is the main reason I became an apprentice. As I was settling in that night, I thought about hanging the photo collage Tanya made me on the wall above my desk so that I could remember why I’m doing this. To have a ton of fun at work and even more fun sight-seeing and adventuring around Chicago with Tanya (when she moves here, of course).

item.title: Newest Obtiva Apprentice
item.dc:creator: Jon

item.content:encoded:
My Journey So Far
Almost two years ago, I started an internship at a small software company in Mankato, MN. My internship landed me a full-time gig where I’ve mainly been creating custom proposal templates and some custom integration applications. After awhile, I started to long for more challenging work. Combined with a want to relocate closer to family and recent experiences with Ruby and Rails, I began to ponder options.

Thanks to someone on Twitter, I was linked to Colin Jones‘ apprenticeship at 8th Light shortly after he started in March 2009. Colin did a great job of blogging his experiences throughout his time as an apprentice and I began thinking that an apprenticeship could be a great way to break into professional software development.

Over the last 20 months or so, I followed several other 8th Light apprentices, Justin Martin, Li-Hsuan Lung, Steve Kim and Steve Degutis, as well as Obtiva apprentices, Ethan Gunderson, Michael Hines and Jen Linder. I really enjoyed reading about all their opportunities and the amount of growth they made as developers. Their willingness to share their experiences enabled me to make the decision to look into an apprenticeship more seriously.

In July, my wife and I stopped in Chicago for a few days on vacation. I was able to visit both Obtiva and 8th Light and gather more information about their apprenticeship programs. I enjoyed meeting with folks at both companies and pairing with a few of them. I especially had a great time pairing with Scott Parker from Obtiva. He went out of his way to make me feel welcome for an afternoon and was patient with me as we worked on adding a new feature to a Rails application. I really felt like Obtiva would be a great fit, both culturally and professional, and I came away from that visit knowing that I wanted to pursue this opportunity.

The Future
A code example and an interview process later, I received word that I was accepted into Obtiva’s apprenticeship program. My wife says she’s never heard me laugh so hard or so long when I was sharing the news with her. It took a few minutes to sink in; I’m the next apprentice at Obtiva. I am really looking forward to starting at Obtiva in 3 weeks and continuing to share my journey.

item.title: Twin Cities Code Camp 9 Recap
item.dc:creator: Jon

item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I attended Twin Cities Code Camp 9. This free developer conference is a great way to socialize with your fellow developers in the Twin Cities area and come away motivated to continue the learning had at the conference.

My morning was filled with two Ruby talks. I was looking forward to the talks by Ryan Briones and Brian Hogan from the time the schedule was announced. I was not disappointed.

Ryan’s Learning Ruby for the Web talk highlighted his argument Rails isn’t the best starting place for new Ruby developers. The main thrust I took away was that Rails is full of abstractions and for beginners they abstract away too much. He looked at lower level Ruby web application development options like Sinatra. This talk has me thinking about framework options other than Rails for any future projects.

Next up was Brian’s talk on Ruby tools in the web developers toolbox. Brian looked at using Haml and Sass as alternatives to writing straight up HTML and CSS, generating static websites with StaticMatic, writing tests using Cucumber, and a brief look at Sinatra. I especially liked Brian’s stance that although these tools come from the Ruby community, that doesn’t forbid .NET or Java developers from using them.

The final talk I was able to attend was Ethan Gunderson’s talk on MongoDB. While I have played around with Mongo in the past, I definitely came away from Ethan’s talk with an increased knowledge of Mongo, especially its write path. Using the default insert options, the Mongo driver returns a success response as soon the the insert is start, without knowing if the data was actually written. But there are options to perform the writes in a “safe mode”. Definitely something to consider when evaluating or working with MongoDB.

Overall I had a great time at Twin Cities Code Camp. It’s a great conference that I look forward to every time it’s on my calendar.
